title: 104_hr857
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Ticket Fee Disclosure Act of 1995". It includes findings related to ticket fees. The Ticket Fee Disclosure Act of 1995 states that sellers and resellers of entertainment and sporting event tickets must disclose all additional charges and fees to consumers. Failure to do so is considered an unfair and deceptive practice under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Ticket Fee Disclosure Act of 1995 requires sellers and resellers of entertainment and sporting event tickets to disclose all additional fees to consumers. The Federal Trade Commission should conduct a study on industry practices to improve consumer access and value. SEC. 3. DISCLOSURE OF SERVICE CHARGES OR ADDITIONAL TICKET FEES. Sellers of entertainment or sporting event tickets must disclose all fees to purchasers before the sale, and the fees must be printed on the ticket or receipt. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce Section 3 of the Act, preventing violations in the same manner as the Federal Trade Commission Act. Violators will be subject to the same privileges and immunities as outlined in the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Federal Trade Commission Act provisions are included in this Act. Violations of section 3 will be treated as violations of the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts. This Act does not limit the authority of the Federal Trade Commission under other laws. SEC. 5. ACTIONS BY STATES.

States can take legal action in federal court to stop violations of section 3, seek damages, restitution, or other relief for their residents.

SEC. 6. STUDY. The Federal Trade Commission will conduct a study on practices related to the sale and resale of entertainment and sporting event tickets. This study will examine practices of promoters, venue owners, artists, athletes, sellers, and resellers, identify charges imposed on ticket purchasers, and evaluate contractual relationships' impact on consumer prices. The study by the Federal Trade Commission will review the practice of combining fees and charges with ticket prices, analyze the effects of consolidations on consumer prices, and examine the withholding of tickets from public sale. The Federal Trade Commission will conduct a study on ticket practices, including the withholding of tickets from public sale and the impact on consumer access to reasonably priced tickets. A report with findings and recommendations on disclosure, fees, and consumer prices for entertainment and sporting event tickets will be submitted to relevant committees within a year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. The term "attorney general" refers to the chief legal officer of a State, and "State" includes any State of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Northern Mariana Islands, and any U.S. territory or possession.
